    Vijay Veerabadran

    I am a Ph.D. student at UC San Diego, where I am advised by Dr. Virginia de Sa. My research spans the fields of Computer Vision, Computational Neuroscience, and Artificial Intelligence.

    • La Jolla, San Diego

    Publications

    Learning long-range spatial dependencies with horizontal gated-recurrent units

    Work in progress, 2018

    In this paper, we introduce a novel recurrent computational unit called the Horizontal Gated Recurrent Unit (hGRU). hGRU complements standard feedforward networks with long-range horizontal connections, the likes of which are found to be useful for solving tasks requiring spatial-contextual influence.

    Recommended citation: Linsley, D., Kim, J., Veerabadran, V., & Serre, T. (2018). Learning long-range spatial dependencies with horizontal gated-recurrent units. arXiv preprint arXiv:1805.08315. https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.08315

    Automated continuous behavioral monitoring and traditional behavioral testing reveal early phenotypes in a novel SOD1-G85R knock-in mouse model of ALS

    Work in progress, 2018

    In this poster, we discuss the identification of early behavioral deficits in the SOD1-G85R mouse model for ALS. We also briefly discuss our automated behavioral monitoring system and its application to efficiently recording and analyzing activities of mice on a massively parallel scale.

    Recommended citation: Will upload soon

    Matrix Sort - A Parallelizable Sorting Algorithm

    International Journal of Computer Applications, 2016

    In this paper, we introduce a novel sorting algorithm that is highly suited for a parallel processing environment. This algorithm is based on a divide-and-conquer strategy wherein the divide phase is massively parallelizable.

    Recommended citation: Kavitha, S., Vijay, V., & Saketh, A. B. (2016). Matrix Sort-A Parallelizable Sorting Algorithm. International Journal of Computer Applications, 143(9). http://vijayvee.github.io/files/matsort.pdf
